incomeExplanation.p1: This chart shows the inflation-adjusted disposable household income over time.
incomeExplanation.p2: An upward trend indicates that household purchasing power is increasing, which generally improves affordability. All figures are adjusted to 2015 currency values to provide a fair comparison across years.
incomeExplanation.p3: The income measured is 'equivalised,' meaning it's adjusted for household size to better compare living standards.

ptiExplanation.p1: This ratio shows how many years of gross household income it would take to buy an average home.
ptiExplanation.p2: A higher ratio means housing is less affordable. All data is inflation-adjusted to 2015 dollars for a fair comparison over time.

mortgageBurdenExplanation.p1: This shows the percentage of gross household income needed to cover the monthly payment on an average home.
mortgageBurdenExplanation.p2: A higher percentage means a greater financial burden. This chart calculates the burden for every year using the same recent interest rate for a fair comparison.
mortgageBurdenExplanation.p3: The 30% line represents a common affordability benchmark. Spending more than this is often considered "housing cost-burdened."

priceToRentExplanation.p1: This index measures the cost of buying a home relative to renting one. It's calculated by dividing the house price index by the rent price index.
priceToRentExplanation.p2: A higher index suggests that house prices are high relative to rental costs. This can indicate that it might be more financially advantageous to rent than to buy.
priceToRentExplanation.p3: The index is set to 100 in 2015. Values above 100 mean buying has become more expensive than renting compared to 2015.

totalHouseholdsExplanation.p1: This chart shows the total number of households in the country over time.
totalHouseholdsExplanation.p2: An increase in the number of households can be a significant driver of housing demand, often leading to upward pressure on prices and rents if supply does not keep pace.
totalHouseholdsExplanation.p3: Factors like population growth, immigration, and changes in living arrangements (e.g., smaller household sizes) all contribute to this trend.

Snapshot.title: Snapshot for {countryName} in {endYear}
Snapshot.subtitle: Based on available data from {startYear} to {endYear}.
Snapshot.ptiUnit: Years of income to buy a home.
Snapshot.explanation1: The inflation-adjusted price of a typical home. This shows the real cost of housing, removing the effects of general price inflation.
Snapshot.explanation2: A ratio of {pti} means it takes that many years of gross household income to buy a home. A higher number is less affordable.
Snapshot.explanation3: The percentage of gross income needed for mortgage payments at current rates. The 30% level is a common affordability benchmark.
Snapshot.explanation4: The estimated time to save a 10% down payment, assuming a household saves 10% of its gross annual income.

AssetPerformanceSimulation.disclaimer: This simulation compares long-term outcomes for buying a home versus renting and investing. It uses simplified assumptions based on historical averages. All figures are inflation-adjusted. These are projections, not predictions — nobody can forecast future markets or housing prices.
AssetPerformanceSimulation.verdictContent: In this scenario, <strong_label>{choice}</strong_label> could leave you wealthier by <strong_accent>{difference}</strong_accent>.

PersonalOutcomeSimulation.disclaimer: This model uses your after-tax (disposable) income and the amount you choose to save each month. It compares a homeowner’s equity against a renter’s invested savings. This is a simplified projection — nobody can predict the future.
PersonalOutcomeSimulation.verdictContent: Based on your inputs, <strong_label>{choice}</strong_label> could result in a higher net worth by <strong_accent>{difference}</strong_accent>.

primarySources.title: Primary Data Sources
primarySources.p1: All core time-series data is sourced from the <link>OECD Data Explorer</link>. The analysis relies on combining several key indicators to construct a consistent, inflation-adjusted view of affordability.

housePrices.title: Analytical House Prices Indicators
housePrices.description: Provides Residential Property Price Indices (RPPIs) used to calculate real house prices, rental prices, and price-to-income ratios. (Last updated: Nov 13, 2025)

income.title: Income Distribution Database (IDD)
income.description: Source for the "Equivalised Household Disposable Income" metric, offering data on income levels, inequality, and poverty. (Last updated: June 16, 2025)

financial.title: Financial Market Indicators
financial.description: The long-term interest rate from this dataset is used as a consistent proxy for mortgage rates across all countries. (Last updated: Nov 10, 2025)

banxico.title: Mexico: Mortgage Market Data
banxico.description: Weighted average interest rates for housing acquisition, sourced directly from <link>Banco de México (Banxico)</link> to ensure accuracy in mortgage burden calculations.

abs.title: Australia: Income Data
abs.description: Real household disposable income growth figures, sourced from the <link>Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS)</link> to address lags in international datasets.

seriesExplained.title: Data Series Explained
seriesExplained.p1: The application calculates key affordability metrics by combining these sources. All metrics are presented in real (inflation-adjusted) terms using 2015 as the baseline year.

realIncome.title: Real Median Income (Equivalised)
realIncome.description: This series uses "Equivalised Household Disposable Income." It adjusts total household income by the number of people in the household to better represent the economic resources available to each member. While the resulting number may appear lower than raw household income, it provides a more accurate comparison of living standards between countries with different average household sizes. The nominal income is then adjusted for inflation using the CPI.

realHousePrice.title: Estimated Real House Price
realHousePrice.description: This value is calculated from the OECD's Real House Price Index, which is anchored to a representative base price for a typical home in 2015. The formula is: (Base Price 2015) × (Index for Year ÷ Index for 2015). This converts the index into an estimated monetary value while maintaining the integrity of the inflation-adjusted trend.

mortgageRate.title: Mortgage Rate Proxy (Long-Term Interest Rate)
mortgageRate.description: To ensure consistency across countries, the app uses the long-term government bond yield (typically 10-year bonds) as a proxy for mortgage rates. This is a standard macroeconomic indicator that moves in close harmony with consumer mortgage rates and accurately reflects changes in borrowing costs over time.

rentToPrice.title: Rent-to-Price Index
rentToPrice.description: This index measures the relative cost of buying a home versus renting one. A higher value suggests that house prices are high relative to rental costs, potentially indicating lower profitability for landlords or that it is more financially advantageous to rent.
